Railtoop from Camden, (N.L) to South .amboy--s
meeting Of the friends of this enterprise was held
at Camden or the 5,h inst for the purpose OF recey
ing MIR. Strickland's report on the subject. From
the character of the country, Mr.. Strickland enter
tains full conviction "tllat the whole line wilb.
found to possess every requisite for double railway
on which the Locomotive Engine and Horse power
NAV be very advantageously used lH the Transports
ton both of passengers and heavy merchandise"
He recommends embankments and wooden bridges
at certain points, .'the construction of which," he
saws, '.wI not be difficult" The soil Of the route
is generally sandy, the best calculated for The
foundation of the road and rails, whether formed OF
wood or cast iron. The proposed route leads through
the most fertile and populous regions oil New Jersey
1t is suggested that, when the Delaware IS obstruc
ed by ice, ships might be ordered to Anboy, and
their cargoes conveyed to Philadelphia by the rail.
way, at an nconslderab!c expense.

Messrs. Gales and Seaton, have announced the
publication of the second volume ui their very valu
able Register, containing the Debates and public
Documents of the first Session Of the Nineteenth
Congress. The arrangement OF the contents is
considered great Improvement upon the first vol.
u,ne, and judiciousy calculated to facilitate rea-
dy references.


The masntude ht q the ha anu ne sheap
may be gathered from the lact that the present vol.
ume alone, consists of sixteen hundred pages of 81.
perroyal octave size and BREWER type, equal to $780,
columns of the National Intelligencer. Of these
1900 pages. the Debates occupy iS40-an appen.
dix of State papers l44-a complete edition Of the
acts passed during the session 87.-'rhe remainder
are devoted to an extensive index The third vol.
ume is in the press and considerably advanced.

NORTH CAROIINA-The friends of the Ad-
ministration have broken ground in North Carolina.
meeting was held at the Court House in Elizabeth
City on Saturday last, s. to devise means and adopt
resolutions to promote the election of John Quincy
Aiams, tried. faithful servant, and civilian in pre-
ference to such man as General Jackson, who
knows no law paramount to his own ambition, obeys
no instructions not in unison with his own despotic
and nturiated imagination, and who, indeed has no
one qualification to recommend him for such high
and dgnitled station, beyond that Of other men, save
that of one military achievement, for which his coun-
lrymen have and are still willing to award to him

As for the result of the election which has Just
terminated in New York let it induce all the friends
of this Administration, Uhan which we have never
had BETTER say what its opponents wlsl.) and all

full articles.headline: From the Baltimore .4mericm.
full articles.article:
Railtoop from Camden, (N.L) to South .amboy--s
meeting Of the friends of this enterprise was held
at Camden or the 5,h inst for the purpose OF recey
ing MIR. Strickland's report on the subject. From
the character of the country, Mr.. Strickland enter
tains full conviction "tllat the whole line wilb.
found to possess every requisite for double railway
on which the Locomotive Engine and Horse power
NAV be very advantageously used lH the Transports
ton both of passengers and heavy merchandise"
He recommends embankments and wooden bridges
at certain points, .'the construction of which," he
saws, '.wI not be difficult" The soil Of the route
is generally sandy, the best calculated for The
foundation of the road and rails, whether formed OF
wood or cast iron. The proposed route leads through
the most fertile and populous regions oil New Jersey
1t is suggested that, when the Delaware IS obstruc
ed by ice, ships might be ordered to Anboy, and
their cargoes conveyed to Philadelphia by the rail.
way, at an nconslderab!c expense.

full articles.headline: From Tie .dlerm,tlria Gazette.
full articles.article:
Messrs. Gales and Seaton, have announced the
publication of the second volume ui their very valu
able Register, containing the Debates and public
Documents of the first Session Of the Nineteenth
Congress. The arrangement OF the contents is
considered great Improvement upon the first vol.
u,ne, and judiciousy calculated to facilitate rea-
dy references.


The masntude ht q the ha anu ne sheap
may be gathered from the lact that the present vol.
ume alone, consists of sixteen hundred pages of 81.
perroyal octave size and BREWER type, equal to $780,
columns of the National Intelligencer. Of these
1900 pages. the Debates occupy iS40-an appen.
dix of State papers l44-a complete edition Of the
acts passed during the session 87.-'rhe remainder
are devoted to an extensive index The third vol.
ume is in the press and considerably advanced.

full articles.headline: From ihe National Journal.
full articles.article:
NORTH CAROIINA-The friends of the Ad-
ministration have broken ground in North Carolina.
meeting was held at the Court House in Elizabeth
City on Saturday last, s. to devise means and adopt
resolutions to promote the election of John Quincy
Aiams, tried. faithful servant, and civilian in pre-
ference to such man as General Jackson, who
knows no law paramount to his own ambition, obeys
no instructions not in unison with his own despotic
and nturiated imagination, and who, indeed has no
one qualification to recommend him for such high
and dgnitled station, beyond that Of other men, save
that of one military achievement, for which his coun-
lrymen have and are still willing to award to him

full articles.headline: PETERSBURG, (Va.) Nov. 3.
full articles.article:
PORK.-We do not remember ever to have seen
so much Pork in our market at as early period in
the season, as at this time. 1t is indeed, quite abun
dant, and theprice ranges from to S4 SO. The guam
tity Of Corn made the present year, will enable
drovers to bring their hogs to market at inconsidera
Bile expense. We may ther fore, from the humber
of hogs expected. calculate upon procuring Pork still
lower (say S3 SOY unless spectators should step in.
to the market, and keep the article up.

One farmer in Connecticut, estimates that when
bis mulberry trees, 500 III number, have come 10
maturity that the ten,aes Of his family, will annual
ly make three hundred pounds Of silk. They made
SO lbs. lat year, by about 100 900 worms, without
feeling any loss of labor. Silk will be extensively
produced IN the United States, especially III the
south.


The vine and the olive tree ought to be added
to the agricultural productions OF the south, 10 eX
change with the middle and east for their nlanuiac
tures &c.


The horses and the hogs of the u. States consume
ten times the amount of all the bread Stuls that we
export, and the single city of New York, with a
supposed population Of 20O,0oo annually consumes
vegetable food equal TO 365,o0o barrels OF loir, OF
one pound for each per diem and 81 millions oi
pounds of meat at three fourhs of pound for each
person, together worth between 4 and 5millions Of
dollars.


Abundance of the carbonate of zinc has been DIS
covered in Missouri, near the Mississippi river.
Brass is formed of copper and zinc.


The glass manufactures of the United States are
worth more than three millions annually. The
capital invested large. The supply except fol
looking glasses, may be sais TO have reached thu
demand, and a considerable quantity will speedll,
pass into our exports. The cutting and otherwise
ornamenting of glass, is perfectly understood an,
extensively practised amongst us.


One factory at Cambrugeport, Mass. makes q
tons ut glue annually. We have some respectab
manufactures of porcelain.


About 400 900 barrels Of salt were supposed I
have been manufactured in western Pennss slyanlt

in the year, Ssh 720 bushels valued AT S677 ,05

land.


1t is calculated that there are in ,'iassachuset
fifteen million OF square feet OF salt WORKS cap

year. Most of those works are in Barnstable cou
ty, along the sandy borders Of Cape Cod, thons
many are to be found further north, and some en- Il
southern coasts.


We have put down the supply of hats at II NJ
lions. The manufacture has been protected.
export them to a handsome amount every year ~
use good and as cheap hats as any other poop
The value OF this manufacture is much uDderratC
we might have supposed il 20 millions. though ma

Many new canals are projected in Ncw-York
some Of them will lie made pretty soon the pl
gress OF Improvement i wonderfully rapid Ses
raj of the beautiful little lakes il that State are 81
piled with Packets or Steamboats,, and the alno,
Of trade already upon them is large. vast qni

hawk and other rivers, and at the outlets Of /

generally ascertained PennsylyanIa is now max
great efforts in the same way, and with every pr
pect Of success, i'll an encouragement Ut the indus
Of her ctxeps. (Po be Contiaucd)


~. L. Lr.

do worse. 70 advance his cause, the success oi
which they have heretofore deprecated AS A CURSE
upon the country, they persecute unrsientlns'y
those whom they have pronounced 10 be his superb
ars, and those also whose only fault has been their
having been partly, but not altogether, Of the same
opinion.


As for the result of the election which has Just
terminated in New York let it induce all the friends
of this Administration, Uhan which we have never
had BETTER say what its opponents wlsl.) and all
the opponents Of the military succession, to stand
firm to their principles to assert the right ami avod
the wrong and to lose no opportunity OF calm and
serious remonsrance with such as are open to CON
vlc,ion, against joining that military party which
has been the bane of all Republics and has sooner
or later produced their downfall. The "Signs OF
the Times" are awful but not appalling instead OF
qaang at their appearance, let them animate our
steps and mark our path to an ultimate triumph,
more glorious than the bloodiest ield-the triumph
of truth and reason, on our side the passions
preluiires Of men which stirred up and arrayed
IN deep phalanx againstus

full articles.article:
I


Events or THE LATE EIECrloN.-That we have |
been disposed 10 speak moderately Of the causes OF
The late Jackson triumph will no doubt be conceded |
We nave not spoken our feelings do we intend
to- But we have facts. and we look for more, OF
such alarming and unprecedented atrocity that we
trcmble to contemplate the results to which they
lead and the degree of wckedness they indicate
We would not -ay it lightly and we would not say
it without proof, and yet do say it. the success
of the Jackson ticket was obtained by fraud. by cio-
lence u9aa intrigue. I cannot be ascertained to
certainty, but no doubt entertained that me thou
sand Irish Votes were polled for Jackson that we're
Illegal. Hundreds of them were dragged to the
polls who had not been in the country three months
1t i, known thar the city swarms with men OF this
description who have landed here within three wears
and who of course cannot have become naturallzed.
But allraliled or not. their votes and their huZZas
for Jackson were deemed legal, or if questioned,
whcA it was dangerous to do At all. the objection
was bea, down by violence, and hickory clubs. We
have names and authority to youch for the fact. that
different carmen were enpIoyed and paid, during


The three days u the election, TO carry cart loads Of


voters first one poll and then to another in the dit
| frrent wards. Instances have come to ligh. where


one carman with six passengers have voted at SIX


different places in the same day. Others have boast
ed. ana now buast publicly. OF having voted. some
/ three and others four times over At moderate





1a kson voters did their duty at least three or four
times. Many Of the wards had no clallengers and


tie only business was to get in the votes Wlthou
{ lquiing at all into their legality.


Il At one ward constable occupied the avenue t.
the ballot boxes, and no voter could obtain acces,
tnrreto without undergoing bis supervision. The in


srcors also IN some Of the wards asss; ID the Jack


son ticket by display Of hickar> branches, and il
one instance opened the ticker Of voter and read
a tloud 10 the company. In an upper ward. wber
' the Irish have full sway. it finally became impossi
e Bile for gentleman American to appear ant
vote at all. II ans one dared to make the expert
nent he was immediately arres ed his votes takei
from him. and Jackson votes put into bis hands; III
pleased him to vote 70 suit them ne could have til
c privilege, otherwise he could leave the poll.
Could the twenty one Thousand votes given at tn


recent election in this city be ,ttea and the iega
5 ones cast away. the eau" Of the admlnlstratlp
n would show a handsome majority. AS tits, we re
Z ard the result. as affecting the great question OF IN
d presidency a5 OF little or no consequence. Bu
. viewed in a mora light. regarded III its bearin
It upon The character of the city, and the safet
a af the rights we boast Of, confess we feel HI


INFLATED and alarmed. On the subject of the on
e sage Of foreigncrs, and the that the Evenir
g Post and others are ready to make of them in OF
e elections, we feel as an American should, and "
q shall not long delay TO speak Of them, AS an Amer
q can may.

From the National LteRgencer, Nou. IS.


No sober-mnded Republican, nne would think i

full articles.article:
Had Mr.. Startling complied with the earnest en-
treaties Of the largest portion of his political friends
and declined the contest like DR.. Naldain of Della
ware, we should have been spared the above morti-
iying result. and he would have entitled himself to
the thanks ofhis fellow citizens.
